</TABLE>


<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more collateral than the outstanding
  exposure, in which case there would not be exposure. As of June 30, 2008, Power had 133 active counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=item4>ITEM 4. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures as defined under Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as
  amended (the Exchange Act) to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in the reports that are filed or submitted under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded,
  processed, summarized and reported and is accumulated and communicated to the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each respective company, as appropriate, by others within the
  entities to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G have established a disclosure committee which includes several key management employees and which reports
  directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure controls and procedures. The
  Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that disclosure
  controls and procedures at each respective company were effective at a reasonable assurance level as of the end of the period covered by the report.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Internal Controls</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G continually review their respective disclosure controls and procedures and make changes, as necessary, to ensure the quality of their financial reporting. There have been no
  changes in internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the second quarter of 2008 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, each registrant&#146;s internal
  control over financial reporting.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">72</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=partii>PART II. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item1>ITEM 1. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G are parties to various lawsuits and regulatory matters in the ordinary course of business. For information regarding material legal proceedings, including updates to information
  reported under Item 3 of Part I of the respective 2007 Annual Reports on Form 10-K of PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G and Item 1 of Part II of the respective Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q of PSEG, Power
  and PSE&amp;G for the quarter ended March 31, 2008, see Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities and Item 5. Other Information, Regulatory Issues.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item1a>ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The risk factors discussed below should be read in conjunction with, and update and supplement the risk factors discussed in PSEG&#146;s, Power&#146;s and PSE&amp;G&#146;s respective Annual Reports on Form 10-K for
  the year ended December 31, 2007 and Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 35 and March 31, 2008 Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. We may be adversely affected by changes in energy deregulation policies, including market design rules.</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The energy industry continues to experience significant change. Our business has been impacted by rules established that create locational capacity markets in each of PJM, New England and New
  York. Under these rules, generators located in constrained areas are paid more for their capacity so there is an incentive to locate in those areas where generation capacity is most needed. While the
  existence of these rules has had a positive impact on Power&#146;s revenues, as its generation in PJM and New England is located in constrained areas, both PJM&#146;s and New England&#146;s locational capacity market
  design rules have been challenged in court. Any changes to these rules may have an adverse impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2008, several state commissions, customer groups and certain federal agencies filed a complaint with FERC against PJM with respect to its RPM.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In July 2008, Power and PSE&amp;G filed a brief with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit due to concerns regarding the manner in which the Cost of New Entry (CONE)
  under RPM is calculated. Other petitioners, including the BPU, also filed briefs.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For additional information on Capacity Market Issues see Item 5. Other Information.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 37 and March 31, 2008 Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. Certain of our leveraged lease transactions at Resources may be successfully challenged by the IRS, which would have a
  material adverse effect on our taxes, operating results and cash flows.</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The IRS has disallowed all deductions associated with certain lease transactions that are similar to a type that the IRS publicly announced its intention to challenge, for tax years 1997 through 2000, and
  2001 through 2003. As of June 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, Resources&#146; total gross investment in such transactions was $1 billion and $1.5 billion, respectively.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">There are several tax cases involving other taxpayers with similar leverage lease investments that are pending. To date, three cases have been decided at the trial court level, two of which were decided
  in favor of the government. An appeal of one of these decisions was recently affirmed. The third case involves a jury verdict that is currently being challenged by both parties on inconsistency grounds.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG believes that its leasing transactions are fully consistent with Resources&#146; long-standing business model and its focus on energy-related assets of the type which PSEG has traditionally owned and
  operated. Based on the status of discussions with the IRS, and considering developments in other cases,<B> </B>PSEG currently anticipates that it will pay $300 million to $350 million in taxes, interest and penalties
  claimed by the IRS for the 1997&#150;2000 audit cycle later in 2008, and subsequently commence litigation to recover a refund.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">If the IRS&#146; disallowance of tax benefits associated with all of these lease transactions was sustained, approximately $1,166 million would become currently payable as of June 30, 2008. This is composed
  of $957</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">73</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">million of deferred tax liabilities that have been recorded under leveraged lease accounting through June 30, 2008 and cumulative interest on this deficiency of $209 million, after-tax. In addition, as of June
  30, 2008, penalties of $147 million have been proposed by the IRS. Interest and penalties grow at the rate of $15 million per quarter. In December 2007, PSEG deposited $100 million with the IRS to defray
  potential interest costs associated with this disputed tax liability. In the event PSEG is successful in its defense of its position, the deposit is fully refundable with interest. A resolution of this matter,
  consistent with the reserves established under FIN 48, could result in additional tax and interest payments approximating $900 million to $950 million, including the amounts for the 1997&#150;2000 audit cycle
  discussed above.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item5>ITEM 5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Certain information reported under the 2007 Annual Report on Form 10-K and Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2008 is updated below. Additionally, certain
  information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2007 Annual Report on Form 10-K and Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2008.
  References are to the related pages on the Form 10-K or March 31, 2008 Form 10-Q as printed and distributed.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>REGULATORY ISSUES</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Federal Regulation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>FERC</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Regulation of Wholesale Sales&#151;Generation/Market Issues</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 15. </I></B>Under FERC regulations, public utilities must receive FERC authorization to sell power in interstate commerce. Public utilities may sell power at cost-based rates or may
  apply to FERC for authority to sell power at market-based rates (MBR). In order to obtain approval to sell power at MBR, FERC must first make a determination that the requesting company lacks
  market power in the relevant markets. Once this determination is made, and MBR authority is granted, the public utility&#146;s individual sales made under the MBR authority are not reviewed or approved by
  FERC but are reported to FERC in quarterly reports.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G, ER&amp;T, Power Connecticut, Fossil and Nuclear submitted MBR filings in January 2008 to FERC in which they asserted that they either lack any generation market power or, if they do possess any
  market power, that market power is being effectively mitigated. They further asserted that, to the extent that FERC analyzes market power held in the small sub-market of Northern PSEG, PJM mitigation
  rules (including price capping for bids) eliminate the potential for the exercise of market power in this sub-market.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FERC issued a decision in April 2008 that (i) eliminates the need for these companies to conduct a market power analysis within the Northern PSEG sub-market; (ii) adopts a rebuttable presumption
  that existing RTO mitigation schemes eliminate any market power concerns; and (iii) requires additional market power studies.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In June 2008, PJM filed a revised transmission capability study for PJM East, which will affect the calculation of import values and potentially impact upon the MBR analysis. In an order issued July 17,
  2008, FERC clarified how MBR sellers should calculate transmission capability in their respective market areas. As a result, PSE&amp;G, ER&amp;T, Power Connecticut, Fossil and Nuclear will file a revised MBR
  analysis based on these recent orders by September 2, 2008. The outcome of this proceeding cannot be predicted.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Capacity Market Issues</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 16.</I></B> RPM is a locational installed capacity market design for the PJM region, including a forward auction for installed capacity. Under RPM, generators located in constrained
  areas within PJM are paid more for their capacity so that they are incented to locate in those areas where generation capacity is most needed. Four PJM capacity auctions covering commitment periods
  extending from June 1, 2007 through May 31, 2011 have been held to date.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">74</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      On July 21, 2008, Power and PSE&amp;G filed a brief with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit due to concerns regarding the manner in which the CONE is calculated.
      Other petitioners&#146; briefs, including the BPU, were also filed.</FONT>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power and PSE&amp;G strongly support the RPM design but believe that certain components of the design, particularly the CONE mechanism, should be modified.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">If the CONE is set too low, generators in the PJM markets may not be adequately compensated for existing capacity and may not have sufficient incentives to construct new generating units.</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      On May 30, 2008, several state commissions, including the BPU and consumer advocate agencies, as well as customer groups and certain federal agencies (RPM Buyers) filed a complaint with FERC
      against PJM with respect to RPM.</FONT>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The complaint challenges the results of the RPM capacity auctions held for the 2008/2009, 2009/2010 and 2010/2011 delivery years. The RPM Buyers assert that various RPM rules permitted suppliers
  to reduce the amount of capacity offered into the auctions, thereby increasing prices, and that PJM&#146;s mitigation measures were inadequate to restrain the exercise of market power in the capacity
  auctions. The RPM Buyers requested that FERC find that the clearing prices produced are unlawful and thus should not be charged to capacity buyers or paid to capacity sellers such as Power, and
  requested refunds, with a refund effective date of May 30, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">This complaint, if granted by FERC, would have a material impact on Power&#146;s transitional auction revenues.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, along with many other auction participants, filed a response with FERC to the RPM Buyers complaint on July 14, 2008. The outcome cannot be predicted.</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      PJM is evaluating ways to improve RPM. PJM retained the Brattle Group, an outside consultant, to prepare a report evaluating the efficacy of the RPM model. This report, which was issued on June
      30, 2008, recommends maintaining the basic design elements of RPM but also proposes changes to RPM that would, among other things, (i) increase the pool of resources that can be bid into RPM,
      e.g. enhancing the ability of efficiency and demand response resources to bid in; (ii) revise the penalty structure for deficiencies and unavailability of capacity resources, perhaps increasing the
      penalties levied on demand resources; (iii) redesign the incremental auction process by creating a single type of incremental auction; and (iv) evaluate and refine the process for calculating the net
      CONE.</FONT>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PJM initiated a stakeholder process to address some or all of the recommendations proposed in the Brattle Group report, which will likely result in a filing by PJM by the end of 2008 with FERC to
  implement certain changes to RPM.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Reactive Power</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2008, ER&amp;T filed with FERC to increase its annual fixed revenues by $18 million to reflect its provision of reactive power support in PJM. Reactive power encompasses certain ancillary services
  necessary to maintain voltage support and operate the system. No protests were filed at FERC regarding the filing, though PJM filed to challenge the proposed effective date. PJM filed comments asking
  FERC not to make the rates effective in May, due to concerns with retroactive billing adjustments, but rather to make the rates effective the first day of the month that FERC approves the filing. As
  requested by FERC, ER&amp;T provided additional support for its filing on July 8, 2008. No protests were filed by the comment date.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">FERC Transmission Regulation</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>PSE&amp;G Transmission Rate Case Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On July 7, 2008, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with FERC to implement a cost of service formula rate for PSE&amp;G&#146;s existing and future transmission investment.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Formula-type rates provide a method of rate recovery where the transmission owner annually determines its revenue requirements through a fixed formula which takes O&amp;M expenditures and capital
  investments and applies an approved Return on Equity (ROE). PSE&amp;G has proposed a forward-looking formula rate mechanism, which has been approved by FERC for other transmission owners. If
  approved, this mechanism would allow PSE&amp;G to update its transmission rates annually based on forecasted O&amp;M and</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">75</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">capital expenditures for the coming year, with no lag of recovery, and would provide for a true-up to actual expenditures in the subsequent year.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G has proposed an ROE of 11.68%, which would include the previously approved 50 basis point adder for RTO membership. While PSE&amp;G has not requested approval in this petition of any
  incentive rates, the formula rate mechanism would provide for recovery of previously-approved transmission rate incentives as well as a mechanism for recovery of any transmission incentives authorized in
  the future. PSE&amp;G has requested an effective date of October 1, 2008. The matter is pending at FERC.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Transmission Rates and Cost Allocation</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 17. </I></B>In 2007, PJM and its members reached a settlement regarding how to allocate costs for new lower voltage (below 500 kilovolts (kV)) transmission expansion. Specifically,
  PJM will use a &#147;beneficiary pays&#148; methodology, identifying the beneficiaries of a particular expansion and allocating costs to those beneficiaries. Power and PSE&amp;G supported this settlement as properly
  allocating costs for such facilities and ensuring that only the correct amounts of costs are allocated to ratepayers. On July 29, 2008, the FERC issued an order approving this settlement. While the settlement
  is quite comprehensive in establishing how to determine the beneficiaries of a particular transmission expansion and allocating the costs to those beneficiaries, the parties could not reach agreement on
  certain issues related to whether and how merchant transmission facilities that have firm rights to export power out of PJM to another region should be included in the beneficiary pays analysis and be
  responsible for a share of the costs of the transmission upgrades. Rather, these issues were set for hearing before FERC. A hearing on these issues was held in May and briefing occurred in June and July. A
  decision is expected from FERC-assigned Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) in September of 2008. While PSEG cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding, PSEG continues to support allocation of cost
  responsibility to these merchant transmission projects as they have a comparable impact on the transmission system as load within PJM.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Transmission Expansion</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 17.</I></B> In June 2007, PSE&amp;G endorsed the construction of three new 500 kV transmission lines intended to address reliability issues of the electrical grid serving New Jersey
  customers. Also in June 2007, PJM approved construction of one of the proposed lines (Susquehanna-Roseland line) and in April 2008, FERC approved incentive rate treatment for the line.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2008, seven state consumer advocates, including the New Jersey Division of Rate Counsel (Rate Counsel), sought rehearing of FERC&#146;s April 2008 order approving the incentive rate treatment.
  In June 2008, PSE&amp;G and PPL filed an answer to this rehearing request, urging FERC to deny the request for rehearing. The rehearing request is currently pending at FERC.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Through the RTEP process, PJM has identified the need for the construction of a 500kV transmission line running from Virginia through Maryland and Delaware and terminating in Salem township.
  PSE&amp;G will be responsible for the constructing and operating a portion of this line, known as the Mid-Atlantic Pathway Project (MAPP). The in-service date has not been finalized. PSE&amp;G&#146;s costs are
  estimated to be approximately $150 million, which are not included in its current capital expenditures forecast.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Con Edison</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In November 2001, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (Con Ed) filed a complaint with FERC against PSE&amp;G, PJM and NYISO asserting a failure to comply with agreements between
  PSE&amp;G and Con Ed covering 1,000 MW of transmission. Both PSE&amp;G and Con Ed have sought judicial review of FERC orders addressing these contracts before the US Court of Appeals for the District of
  Columbia Circuit. The matter remains pending.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The agreements expire in May 2012. On April 22, 2008, pursuant to FERC rules that permit holders of long-term transmission rights to extend their entitlements, PJM filed contracts with FERC which
  would extend until 2017 the transmission service that is the subject of the disputed agreements between PSE&amp;G and Con Ed. PSE&amp;G has protested PJM&#146;s filing. This protest is pending at FERC.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">76</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G is unable to predict the outcome of these proceedings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Power</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Additional NRC Oversight</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 19.</I></B> Power has been advised by the NRC that Salem Unit 1 will be subject to additional oversight. The additional NRC oversight is due to a negative change in the performance
  indicator related to the plant&#146;s diesel back-up power system. This increased oversight will include a supplemental inspection to provide assurance that the problem has been adequately addressed. Power will
  continue to be under heightened oversight until inspection and reviews are completed by the NRC in the fourth quarter of 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>State Regulation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>SBC Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 20. </I></B>The SBC is a mechanism designed to insure recovery of costs associated with activities required to be accomplished to achieve specific government mandated public policy
  determinations. The programs that are covered by the SBC (gas and electric) are energy efficiency and renewable energy programs, Manufactured Gas Plant RAC and the USF. In addition, the electric SBC
  includes a Social Programs component. All components include interest on both over and under recoveries.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a motion with the BPU seeking approval of changes in its electric and gas SBC rates and its electric non-utility generation charge (NGC) rates. A revised motion was filed in
  October 2007. In June 2008 PSE&amp;G received the ALJ&#146;s Initial Decision disallowing a portion of its claimed lost revenues. The ALJ granted an electric increase of $89.7 million compared to $89.8 million
  requested and a gas increase of $15.2 million compared to PSE&amp;G&#146;s request of $16.7 million. Exceptions and reply exceptions were filed in July 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>BGSS</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 21.</I></B> BGSS is the mechanism approved by the BPU designed to recover all gas costs related to the supply for residential customers. BGSS filings are made annually by June 1 of
  each year, with an effective date of October 1. Revenues are matched with costs using deferred accounting, with the goal of achieving a zero cumulative balance by September 30 of each year.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2008, PSE&amp;G requested an increase in annual BGSS revenues of $376 million, excluding Sales and Use Tax, to be effective October 1, 2008. This represents an approximate 20% increase on a
  typical residential gas customer&#146;s bill. Based on discussions with the BPU Staff, PSE&amp;G submitted a proposed Stipulation of the Parties that would place the filed rate into effect on October 1, 2008 on a
  provisional basis, subject to refund. The matter is currently pending at the BPU.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Solar Initiative</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 22. </I></B>In<B><I> </I></B>April 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a plan with the BPU designed to spur investment in solar power in New Jersey and meet energy goals under the EMP. This program received final
  BPU approval and a written BPU order in April 2008. Under the plan, PSE&amp;G will invest approximately $105 million over two years in a pilot program to help finance the installation of 30 MW of solar
  systems throughout its electric service area. PSE&amp;G will provide loans to customers in its electric service territory for the installation of solar photovoltaic systems on the customers&#146; premises. The borrowers
  can repay the loans over a period of either 10 years (for residential customer loans) or 15 years (for all other loans) by providing PSE&amp;G with solar renewable energy certificates (SRECs). Borrowers will also
  have the option to repay the loans with cash.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The program will support 30 MW of solar power, fulfilling approximately 50% of the BPU&#146;s Renewal Portfolio Standard requirements in PSE&amp;G&#146;s service area in May 2009 and May 2010.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">77</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G will be allowed a return of 11.11% on invested capital, including income tax effects. The program was opened up to non-residential customers on April 17, 2008. As of June 30, 2008, applications
  have been received for approximately 38.5% of the 30 MW program. Beginning July 2008, the program became available to residential customers. The BPU is also considering whether additional measures
  are needed to stimulate solar development in New Jersey. A stakeholder working group was recently concluded, focusing on such issues as whether New Jersey utilities like PSE&amp;G should be required to
  purchase SRECs from solar developers to stimulate the market. PSE&amp;G has proposed to continue working within the construct of its solar loan program, and to potentially expand the program or extend its
  duration.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>New Jersey Energy Master Plan (EMP)</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 22.</I></B> State law in New Jersey requires that an EMP be developed every three years, the purpose of which is to ensure safe, secure and reasonably-priced energy supply, foster
  economic growth and development and protect the environment. A draft EMP was released in April 2008 with a final plan expected to be completed later in the year. It proposes a number of the actions to
  improve energy efficiency and increase the use of renewable resources and clean central station power for addressing climate change, including to:</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      conduct a complete review of the BGS auction process;</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">maximize energy conservation and energy efficiency to reduce New Jersey&#146;s projected energy use by 20% by the year 2020;</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">reduce prices by decreasing peak demand by 5,700 MW by 2020;</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">meet 22.5% of New Jersey&#146;s electricity needs from renewable sources;</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">develop new low carbon emitting, efficient power plants to help close the gap between the supply and demand of electricity;</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">invest in innovative clean energy technologies and businesses to stimulate the industry&#146;s growth in New Jersey; and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">consider the establishment of a state power authority or a state energy council.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G has expressed its desire to be a partner to the State in the EMP. To this end PSE&amp;G has proposed several programs in filings with the BPU addressing different components of the EMP goals, has
  submitted a number of strategies designed to improve efficiencies in customer use and increase the level of renewable generation and has been actively involved in the broad-based constituent working
  groups created to develop these strategies. PSEG and PSE&amp;G participated in the EMP roundtable discussions conducted by the State of New Jersey in June 2008 and will participate in upcoming public
  proceedings to review the conclusions and recommendations of the EMP.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) Technologies</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 22.</I></B> In December 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the BPU requesting expedited approval to deploy and test AMI technologies, to enable customers to monitor energy use,
  conserve energy, reduce costs during peak periods and reduce CO2 emissions that contribute to global climate change. In June 2008, the BPU approved a pilot program. PSE&amp;G is in the initial design stages.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Carbon Abatement Program</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2007 Form 10-K, Page 22. </I></B>In December 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the BPU seeking expedited approval of a carbon abatement pilot program. This filing was withdrawn on May 1, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">A petition for approval for a small scale carbon abatement program was filed with the BPU in June 2008 seeking approval under the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) legislation which was
  signed into law in January 2008. PSE&amp;G proposes to invest up to $46 million over four years in programs across specific customer segments. The program is designed to support the State&#146;s EMP goals and
  promote energy efficiency. PSE&amp;G has requested a return on this investment at its established rate. The matter is currently pending. This amount is not included in PSE&amp;G&#146;s projected capital expenditures.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">78</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<B><FONT size=2 face="serif">EXHIBIT 12 </FONT></B></P>
<P align="center">
<B><FONT face="serif">PUBLIC SERVICE</FONT></B><B><FONT size=1 face="serif"> </FONT></B><B><FONT face="serif">ENTERPRISE GROUP INCORPORATED</FONT></B><B><FONT size=1 face="serif"> </FONT></B><BR>
<B><FONT face="serif">COMPUTATION OF RATIOS OF EARNINGS TO FIXED CHARGES </FONT></B></P>

  <TD align=left width=16%>&nbsp;  </TD>

  <TD width=1% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD align=right width=5% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">
<FONT size=1 face="serif">2.41</FONT>  </TD>
  <TD align=left width=5% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD width=1% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD align=right width=3% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD width=1% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD align=right width=5% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">
<FONT size=1 face="serif">2.32</FONT>  </TD>
  <TD align=left width=3% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD width=2% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD align=right width=2% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD width=2% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
  <TD align=right width=7% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">
<FONT size=1 face="serif">2.27</FONT>  </TD>
  <TD align=left width=2% style="border-bottom:3px double #000000;">&nbsp;  </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<BR>
<TABLE border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
<TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top><FONT size=1 face="serif">(A)</FONT>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;   </TD>
  <TD width=100%>
    <div align="left"><FONT size=1 face="serif">The term &#147;earnings&#148; shall
        be defined as pre-tax Income from Continuing Operations before income
        or loss from equity investees plus distributed income from equity investees.
        Add to pre-tax income the amount of fixed charges adjusted to exclude
        (a) the amount of any interest capitalized during the period and (b)
        the actual amount of any preferred securities dividend requirements of
    majority-owned subsidiaries stated on a pre-tax level.</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top><FONT size=1 face="serif">(B)</FONT>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;   </TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b) amortization of debt discount, premium and expense, (c) an estimate of interest implicit in rentals and (d) preferred securities dividend
requirements of majority-owned subsidiaries stated on a pre-tax level.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR><TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">(C)</FONT>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;   </TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">Capitalized Interest excludes AFUDC for PSE&amp;G.</FONT>  </TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=2>


</BODY>

</HTML>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<table width="100%" border="0">
  <tr>
    <td valign="top"><FONT size=1 face="serif">(A) &nbsp;
</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=1 face="serif">The term "earnings" shall be defined as pre-tax  Income from Continuing Operations.  Add to pre-tax  income the amount of fixed charges adjusted to exclude the amount of any interest capitalized during the period.
</FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td><FONT size=1 face="serif">(B) </FONT><FONT size=1 face="sans-serif">
</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=1 face="serif">Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b) amortization of debt discount, premium and expense and (c) an estimate of interest implicit in rentals. </FONT><FONT size=1 face="sans-serif">
</FONT></td>
  </tr>
</table>

<BR>
<TABLE width="100%" border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">(A)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">The term "earnings" shall be defined as pretax income from continuing operations. Add to pretax income the amount of fixed charges adjusted to exclude the amount of any interest capitalized during the period.</FONT>  </TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR><TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">(B)</FONT></TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b) amortization of debt discount, premium and expense and (c) an estimate of interest implicit in rentals.</FONT>  </TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>

<BR>
<TABLE border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
<TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">(A)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">The term "earnings" shall be defined as pretax income from continuing operations. Add to pretax income the amount of fixed charges adjusted to exclude (a) the amount of any interest capitalized during the period (b) the
actual amount of any preferred securities dividend requirements of majority owned subsidiaries (c) preferred stock dividends which were included in such fixed charges amount but not deducted in the determination of pre-tax income.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR><TR>
  <TD nowrap valign=top>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">(B)</FONT></TD>
  <TD width=100%>
<FONT size=1 face="serif">Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b) amortization of debt discount and premium expense (c) an estimate of interest implicit in rentals and (d) preferred securities dividend requirements
of majority owned subsidiaries and preferred stock dividends, increased to reflect the pre-tax earnings requirement for PSE&amp;G.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD colspan=2>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P align=right><B><FONT face=serif size=2>EXHIBIT 31 </FONT></B></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=serif>Certification Pursuant to Rules 13a-14 and 15d-14 </FONT></B><BR>
<B><FONT face=serif>of the 1934 Securities Exchange Act </FONT></B></P>
<TABLE cellSpacing=1 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=center width="98%" colSpan=5><div align="left"><FONT face=serif size=2>I, Ralph Izzo, certify that:</FONT>&nbsp; </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>1.</FONT></TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="92%" colSpan=3 align=left valign="top"><FONT face=serif size=2>I have reviewed this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated;</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" rowspan="2" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>2.</FONT>&nbsp;  </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="92%" colSpan=3 rowSpan=3 align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a
       material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such
    statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;</FONT>&nbsp; </div></TD>
</TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD></TR>

<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" rowspan="3" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>3.</FONT></TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="92%" colSpan=3 rowSpan=3 align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;</FONT></div></TD></TR>

<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>4.</FONT>&nbsp;    </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="92%" colSpan=3 align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>The registrant's
       other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and
       procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial
       reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and
    have:</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>


<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>(a)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>



<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(b)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>



<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(c)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>


<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(d)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Disclosed in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>


<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>5.</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="92%" colSpan=3 align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>The registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>


<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(a)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>


<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(b)</FONT>&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" rowSpan=2 align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting.</FONT></div></TD>
</TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="7%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD></TR></TABLE>

<P align=right><FONT face=serif size=2></FONT><B><FONT face=serif size=2>EXHIBIT 31.3 </FONT></B></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=serif>Certification Pursuant to Rules 13a-14 and 15d-14 </FONT></B><BR>
<B><FONT face=serif>of the 1934 Securities Exchange Act </FONT></B></P>
<TABLE cellSpacing=1 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

     <TD align=left width="98%" colSpan=5><FONT face=serif size=2>I, Thomas M. O&#146;Flynn, certify that:</FONT> </TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>1.</FONT> </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="92%" colSpan=3><FONT face=serif size=2>I have reviewed this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q of PSEG Power LLC;</FONT> </TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>2.</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="92%" colSpan=3><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>3.</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="92%" colSpan=3><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; &nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>4.</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="92%" colSpan=3><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>The registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:</FONT> </div></TD></TR>

<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(a)</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="83%"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(b)</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="83%"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(c)</FONT> </TD>
     <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
  <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and</FONT> </div></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(d)</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
  <TD align=left width="83%"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Disclosed in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and</FONT> </div></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>5.</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD align=left width="92%" colSpan=3><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>The registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD align=left width="4%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="7%" align=left valign="top">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(a)</FONT> </TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp; </TD>
     <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and</FONT> </div></TD></TR>
<TR>
     <TD width="98%" colSpan=5>&nbsp; </TD></TR>
<TR vAlign=bottom>
     <TD width="4%" align=left valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
    <TD align=left width="7%">&nbsp; <FONT face=serif size=2>(b)</FONT> </TD>
     <TD width="2%" valign="bottom">&nbsp; </TD>
  <TD width="83%" align=left valign="top"><div align="justify"><FONT face=serif size=2>Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting.</FONT> </div></TD>
</TR></TABLE><BR>

<P align=right><B><FONT face=serif size=2>EXHIBIT 32 </FONT></B></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=serif>Certification Pursuant to Section 1350 of Chapter 63 of Title 18 </FONT></B><BR>
<B><FONT face=serif>of the United States Code </FONT></B></P>
<P align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face=serif size=2>I, Ralph Izzo, Chief Executive Officer
of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated, to the best of my knowledge, certify that (i) the
Quarterly Report of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated on Form 10-Q for the period ended June 30,
2008 (the "Report") fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934 and (ii) the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material
respects, the financial condition and results of operations of Public Service Enterprise
Group Incorporated. </FONT></P>
